==Personal life==
Since gaining national and international attention as a high school phenom, Ohtani is Japan's most celebrated athlete<ref name=LATimesYouth /> and has faced intense media pressure scrutiny with the Japanese press his whole adult life.<ref name=OhtaniOrigins /> Due to the high-profile nature of his two-way efforts, the Fighters protected Ohtani from some of the media onslaught, while Ohtani tended to keep to the team dormitory and the gym, leading a semi-monastic, baseball-centric existence, a byproduct for holding down two jobs in the big leagues and doing both at an elite level.<ref name=OhtaniOrigins />

While not fluent, Ohtani can speak English and knows Spanish, but prefers to speak to the media through an interpreter, translating his native Japanese to English.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bumbaca |first=Chris  |date=July 12, 2021 |title=Stephen A. Smith on Shohei Ohtani: 'Don't think it helps that the No. 1 face is a dude that needs an interpreter' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/angels/2021/07/12/stephen-a-smith-shohei-ohtani-dude-needs-interpreter/7939597002/ |access-date=October 7, 2021 |website=USA Today}}</ref> [[Ippei Mizuhara]] is Ohtani's personal interpreter with the Los Angeles Angels and has known him since Ohtani was 18, starting in 2013 during Ohtani's days with the Fighters.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bollinger |first=Rhett  |date=July 10, 2021 |title=Ohtani's interpreter to catch in HR Derby |url=https://www.mlb.com/news/shohei-ohtani-interpreter-ippei-mizuhara-to-catch-in-2021-home-run-derby |access-date=October 7, 2021 |website=MLB.com}}</ref> Mizuhara's role as Ohtani's personal interpreter ranges from confidante to conditioning coach and throwing partner, to making sure Ohtani understands, and is understood.<ref name="OhtaniIppei">{{Cite web |last=O'Connell |first=Robert  |date=June 21, 2021 |title='A Game of Speech'—But Also, For Baseball Interpreters, So Much More |url=https://www.si.com/mlb/2021/06/21/baseball-interpreters-daily-cover |access-date=October 8, 2021 |website=Sports Illustrated}}</ref> The interpreter steps into any number of sub-duties, including Ohtani's agenda—preparation, play, recovery, media availability, breaking down advanced analytics and recovery timetables between Ohtani and the Angels organization.<ref name="OhtaniIppei" /> After Ohtani joined the Angels, Mizuhara suggested to Ohtani, as an icebreaker, to combine his hobby of playing video games by downloading ''[[Clash Royale]]'' with the rest of the clubhouse.<ref name="OhtaniIppei" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Gonzalez |first=Alden  |date=September 12, 2019 |title=Shohei Ohtani can hit, pitch -- and keep his teammates laughing |url=https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/27597381/shohei-ohtani-hit-pitch-keep-teammates-laughing |access-date=October 8, 2021 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref>

When Ohtani announced in September 2017 that he wanted to pursue a career in MLB,<ref name="auto3" /> he signed with [[Creative Artists Agency|CAA Sports]] for representation. Ohtani is represented by [[Sports agent|agent]] Nez Balelo of [[Creative Artists Agency|CAA Sports]] since 2017.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hernández |first=Dylan |date=November 6, 2017 |title=Japanese star Shohei Ohtani reportedly chooses CAA Sports to represent him in the U.S., a sign he's ready to play in the majors |url=https://www.latimes.com/sports/mlb/la-sp-shohei-ohtani-agency-20171106-story.html |access-date=September 15, 2021 |website=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> Ohtani was listed in [[Forbes 30 under 30|''Forbes'' 30 under 30 Asia]] class of 2018 in the field of Entertainment & Sports.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/30-under-30-asia/2018/entertainment-sports/#34030a6d551d |title=30 UNDER 30 ENTERTAINMENT & SPORTS |work=Forbes |access-date=December 8, 2021}}</ref>

For his historic campaign in 2021, Ohtani was named to [[Time 100|''Time'' 100]]'s list of most influential people of 2021 <ref name="auto" /> and awarded the [[Commissioner's Historic Achievement Award]] by Commissioner [[Rob Manfred]].<ref name="commissioner" /> Additionally, Ohtani's 2021 season was recognized for two [[Guinness World Records]] titles: (1) the first MLB player to achieve 100+ innings and record 100+ strikeouts as a pitcher, and 100+ RBIs, hits and runs as a batter in a single season and (2) the first player to start the [[2021 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|MLB All-Star Game]] as a pitcher and a designated hitter.<ref name="Tokyo Tower to light the sky in Ang"/> Ohtani was also offered Japan's national honor, the [[People's Honour Award#cite note-declined-11|People's Honour Award]], by the [[Prime Minister of Japan]] in recognition of his accomplishments, but Ohtani rejected it, saying it was "still too early" for such an award.<ref name="reuters.com"/>

===Endorsements===

In August 2022, Ohtani became a brand ambassador for [[Porsche|Porsche Japan]] as part of their 'Porsche Driving Athlete' family.<ref>{{cite web |date=August 19, 2022 |title=Los Angeles Angels superstar Shohei Ohtani looks slick in a photo shoot for Porsche |url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/baseball/news-look-los-angeles-angels-superstar-shohei-ohtani-looks-slick-photo-shoot-porsche |access-date=October 7, 2022 |website=sportskeeda}}</ref>

{{As of|April 2022}}, Ohtani endorsement earnings tripled from 2021 to an estimated MLB league-leading $20 million off the field, proving to be a marketing hit on both sides of the Pacific, with a group of 15 partnerships that included renewals among his partners Fanatics, [[Topps]] and [[Panini Group|Panini]] in the U.S. and [[Asics]], [[Descente]] and [[Hugo Boss]] in Japan, as well as new deals with [[FTX (company)|FTX]], [[Kowa (company)|Kowa]], [[MUFG_Bank|Mitsubishi Bank]] and [[Salesforce]].<ref name="Forbes22">{{cite web |last=Birnbaum |first=Justin |date=April 6, 2022 |title=Thanks To A Show-Stopping 2021, Shohei Ohtani's Endorsement Earnings Have Tripled In A Year |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/justinbirnbaum/2022/04/06/thanks-to-a-show-stopping-2021-shohei-ohtanis-endorsement-earnings-tripled-in-a-year/?sh=43dadc57dd2f |access-date=April 21, 2022 |website=Forbes.com}}</ref>

Ohtani is the cover athlete of ''[[MLB The Show 22]]''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Russell |first=Ramone |date=January 31, 2022  |title=Shohei Ohtani: Unanimous AL MVP is your MLB The Show 22 cover athlete |url=https://blog.playstation.com/2022/01/31/shohei-ohtani-unanimous-al-mvp-is-your-mlb-the-show-22-cover-athlete/ |access-date=January 31, 2022 |website=playstation.com |publisher=PlayStation Blog}}</ref> and is the first Asian player to be featured as the cover star of ''[[MLB: The Show]]'', as well as the first Asian athlete to be featured on the cover of a video game in the United States centered on the four major sports.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Russell |first=Ramone |date=January 31, 2022  |title=Los Angeles Angels star Shohei Ohtani on cover of MLB the Show 22 |url=https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/33185669/los-angeles-angels-star-shohei-ohtani-cover-sony-mlb-show-22-video-game |access-date=January 31, 2022 |website=espn.com |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> On February 9, 2022, Ohtani appeared in the [[Nintendo Direct]] to promote ''MLB The Show 22'', as it was the first installment in the franchise to appear on a Nintendo console. In the direct, two versions of Ohtani, one in hitting gear, the other in pitching gear, stood side by side holding devices. The use of Ohtani to promote it was seen as tying to his Japanese nationality, as [[Nintendo]] is based in Japan.<ref>{{Cite web |date=9 February 2022 |title=MLB The Show 22 - Gameplay Reveal - Nintendo Switch |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O2BCgpVwZ1Q.html |website=YouTube |publisher=Nintendo |language=en}}</ref>

On July 20, 2021, Ohtani signed an exclusive multiyear memorabilia deal with [[Fanatics (sports retailer)|Fanatics]].<ref name="Fanatics">{{cite web |last=Hajducky|first=Dan |date=July 20, 2021 |title=Los Angeles Angels' Shohei Ohtani lands exclusive memorabilia deal with Fanatics |url=https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/31845271/los-angeles-angels-shohei-ohtani-lands-exclusive-memorabilia-deal-fanatics |access-date=July 21, 2021 |website=Forbes}}</ref>
